sec.title: Aim
sec.p: The COVID-19 epidemic has caused risk and uncertainty. This study answers whether and how psychological distress and digital sports influence willingness to take the vaccine and precautionary savings.

sec.title: Subject and methods
sec.p: We conducted a cross-sectional study with an online survey sample of 1016 Shanghai residents who live and work there and are aged between 16–60. All of them experienced the COVID-19 lockdown in Shanghai. We used logistic regressions to examine the relationships between the variables of interest.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Three findings were demonstrated. First, psychologically distressed individuals are less inclined to take the vaccine. Second, those engaged in fitness activities via digital media platforms are more willing to get vaccinated. Third, psychologically distressed individuals and digital video-based physical exercisers are more likely to precautionary save.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study contributes to the literature by documenting how people changed their life from the perspective of finance and health during the lockdown and providing practical implications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: COVID-19 has spread globally (Lucini et al. 2020) and brings many challenges which could harm health and well-being (Low et al. 2021). Rapid changes and new policy rules push individuals to adapt to a new lifestyle (Soeroto and Asriputri 2021). Lockdowns happened in many places, and recently in Shanghai in 2022, which required remote working and studying, limited face-to-face social interactions and group events, caused economic loss, and raised physical conditions and psychological distress with less medical support (Low et al. 2021).

Physical health is vital; hence, regular exercise is crucial to enhancing the immune system and maintaining physical well-being (Lange and Nakamura 2020). Nevertheless, gyms are forced to be closed, and outdoor sports activities are significantly reduced due to contact restrictions (Ruth et al. 2022). Alternatively, digital sports have become prevalent and widely accepted, inspiring people to stay physically active and form a healthy lifestyle. During the pandemic, the research on the potential benefits of digital media-based sports activities gained attention.

Mental health is also essential, and many people struggle during the pandemic, resulting in mental disorders such as depression and anxiety (Rodríguez-González et al. 2020). In particular, quarantine and isolation measures could potentially trigger psychological effects on vulnerable groups (Holmes et al. 2020) and subsequently cause self-harm, suicide, fear, and psychological distress (Brooks et al. 2020). Therefore, the research on other possible effects of mental health on one’s life well-being and interventions to mitigate it deserve attention.

The COVID-19 vaccine rollout achieved diverse levels of success in different nations. Achieving a high percentage of vaccine coverage is essential to alleviating the pandemic’s negative effect on health, the elder care systems, and the community (Peters 2022). In addition, people tend to save resources and increase safe savings to handle future uncertainties and risks (Jin et al. 2021). For example, a survey reports that more than 50% of Chinese households increased their savings during the pandemic (Survey and Research Center for China Household Finance 2020). Consequently, studying determinants of vaccine coverage and precautionary savings has implications.

Previous studies find that the vaccine rate of COVID-19 is low among those with mental illness (Brewer and Abad 2021), and keeping fit helps to improve cognitive function (Tomporowski and Pesce 2019), which further influences vaccine hesitancy (Martinelli and Veltri 2021). Therefore, we aim to answer whether and how psychological distress and digital sports influence the willingness to vaccinate.

In addition, prior studies report that psychological distress increases the probability of safe savings (Bogan and Fertig 2013). Individuals who are depressed feel it is challenging to manage their daily routine and subsequently are more inclined to avoid complex things requiring cognitive effort, such as changing the allocation of their financial assets (Lindeboom and Melnychuk 2015). Furthermore, other studies demonstrate that physical exercise motivates cognitive functions (Tilp et al. 2020), increasing prudence (Breaban et al. 2016). Prudent individuals are more likely to save in advance to buff unforeseen expenditures shocks (Lugilde et al. 2019). Thus, another intention is to answer whether and how psychological distress and digital media-based sports activities influence precautionary saving.

Therefore, a cross-sectional study is conducted with an online survey sample of 1016 Shanghai citizens living there during the lockdown period (Feb to June 2022). We use Spearman’s correlation to describe data patterns and use logistic regression models to estimate. There are three findings. First, individuals with psychological depression are less likely to get vaccinated. Second, engaging in digital sports is associated with the willingness to accept vaccines. Third, psychologically distressed individuals and digital video-based physical activities motivate precautionary saving. We propose plausible mechanisms to explain these relationships and implications for theory and practice.

sec.title: Mental health, digital sports at home, and the willingness to get the COVID-19 vaccine
sec.p: The rollout of COVID-19 vaccines has reached different levels of success in many nations (Peters 2022). Macroscopic factors that influence the rollout of COVID-19 vaccines include the ability to afford financially (Wouters et al. 2021), supply (Alam et al. 2021), production (Feinmann 2021), distributing capability (Mills and Salisbury 2021), and public misperception (Mac et al. 2021). Microscopic factors, which can influence the willingness to take the vaccine, are various, for instance, accessibility (Rosen et al. 2021), health literacy (Lorini et al. 2018), decision to tradeoff decision between risk and benefit (Patelarou et al. 2022), cultural and beliefs (Agarwal et al. 2021), trust in government (Quinn and Andrasik 2021), etc.

Governments and political powers are crucial in promoting vaccine uptakes (Peters 2022), influencing citizens’ choices about getting vaccinated. Due to a large population base, Chinese authorities have made an enormous effort to prevent and control the spreading of the COVID-19 virus and its variants (Yang et al. 2021). In 2020, the general intention rate to take the COVID-19 vaccine was 88.9% (Lin et al. 2020). Afterward, a national vaccination program targeting 18–59 years old people was launched. Since May 2021, an average of 19 million doses were vaccinated every day in June, indicating its fast progress and success in vaccine rollout. Therefore, government interventions could significantly increase the intention rate and vaccine rate.

Meanwhile, a Canadian study reports that demographic factors (e.g., age, social-economic status, education, and health literacy) and individual difference factors (e.g., risk aversion, disgust sensitivity) influence the willingness to vaccinate. Specifically, we aim to identify whether psychological distress and engaging in home-based digital sports are similar to individual factors above that predict one’s intention to take the vaccine, which is due to the fact that citizens experience rapid depression during the lockdown (Wong et al. 2021), and doing exercises based on online courses at home became prevalent (Mutz et al. 2021), during the pandemic.

In the literature, mental health is associated with vaccine uptake. First, the relationship between stress and the COVID-19 epidemic has been documented, and there are diverse findings (Klinkhammer et al. 2022). For example, one American study (Gerretsen et al. 2021) reports that individuals with more significant mental illnesses are less likely to get vaccinated because of the epidemic. Similar findings are documented that individuals living in Portugal, who feel nervous, sad, and anxious every day caused by social distance rules during the pandemic, are more inclined to refuse the corresponding vaccine (Soares et al. 2021). Second, depression and anxiety influence vaccine hesitancy aside from stress (Klinkhammer et al. 2022). For instance, some papers’ findings indicate that depression and anxiety are negatively associated with vaccine hesitancy in the Irish and British samples (Murphy et al. 2021; Urrunaga-Pastor et al. 2021). However, other researchers state that no such relationship has been detected (Butter et al. 2022). Since psychological distress symptoms increased during the pandemic, this study investigates how mental health problems influence the Chinese sample’s willingness to get the vaccine. We aim to contribute to the literature by reporting new empirical evidence in Chinese society and bringing implications in terms of interventions for vaccine hesitancy. The first hypothesis is as follows:
Hypothesis 1: The severity of psychological distress has a significant adverse effect on the willingness to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

Do physical exercises influence the willingness for COVID-19 vaccination? The direct empirical evidence regarding the relationship between physical activity and vaccine hesitancy is not yet documented. Regular physical exercise during the pandemic is vital to enhance immunity and achieve physical well-being (Lange and Nakamura 2020). Taking COVID-19 vaccines is also essential to prevent being infected. A US study reported that vaccine hesitancy is influenced by believing the vaccine is effective and risk-free and realizing the value of the vaccine (Soeroto and Asriputri 2021). Cognitive processing affects vaccine hesitancy (Martinelli and Veltri 2021) based on health behavior models (Fishbein and Ajzen 2011), which consider individuals rational to chase the best consequence and maximize expected utility.

Meanwhile, physical exercise helps enhance cognitive function (Tomporowski and Pesce 2019). Therefore, we propose that exercise training could increase the willingness to take the vaccine. Given the restrictive rules of going out and the prevalence of digital media-based home exercise (Parker et al. 2021), the second hypothesis is as follows:
Hypothesis 2: digital media-based physical exercises are positively associated with the willingness to get the COVID-19 vaccine.

sec.title: Mental health, digital sports at home, and precautionary saving
sec.p: Saving and spending are vital to individual financial decisions, affecting economic development and growth (Jin et al. 2021). Hence, economists have focused on life-saving choices for a long time (Bahaddin et al. 2019), and many economic theories have been established, for instance, the precautionary savings hypothesis (Leland 1978). Since these hypotheses support economics model research from a macroeconomic perspective, attention to microeconomic research topics and consumer psychology is required (Jin et al. 2021). Previous studies report that consumers are inclined to increase household savings to cope with the cost of unexpected emergencies (Drèze and Modigliani 1975), such as unemployment risk, the Great Recession (Mody et al. 2012), family disruption (Pericoli and Ventura 2012), medical and nursing home expenses (Kopecky and Koreshkova 2014), environment risk (Baiardi et al. 2016), contagious diseases (Baiardi et al. 2020), etc. Therefore, other than wealth, these dimensions can influence the utility of wealth and will be changeable in the future (Baiardi et al. 2020).

These dimensions are labeled as “background risks” referring to the conditions where household saving decisions are made. Given that Eeckhoudt et al. (2007) introduce background risk into saving analysis and put forward to move from univariate utility to bivariate utility function, and Baiardi et al. (2020) state households tend to increase more savings when background risk exists, we study the effect of mental health and physical activities on the willingness to precautionary save during the lockdown.

Mental health is vital to the quality of life, well-being, and household wealth (Geirdal et al. 2021; Balloch et al. 2022). According to classical theories (Baiardi et al. 2020) and empirical findings (Jin et al. 2021), the COVID-19 pandemic will increase savings. When this public risk exists, how will psychological distress influence precautionary saving? First, studies find that psychological distress lowers the probability of taking risky financial assets (Lindeboom and Melnychuk 2015; Knüpfer et al. 2017) and holding assets in retirement accounts (Bogan and Fertig 2018) but raises the probability of saving (Bogan and Fertig 2013). Shifting assets from risky to safe could indicate a change in risk perception due to mental health shock (Edwards 2010) during the pandemic. This channel is documented to make one afraid of taking risks and become more pessimistic in assessing the probability of gains and losses (Lindeboom and Melnychuk 2015), raising risk aversion (Smoski et al. 2008). Second, previous studies report that depressed individuals are more likely to have difficulties in managing their daily routines and, after that, tend to avoid things that require high cognitive effort, for instance, changing the allocation of their financial assets (Lindeboom and Melnychuk 2015). Therefore, cognitive processing could be the second possible channel, indicating stressed individuals turn to be passive and increase a saving buffer. Based on the above arguments, we propose the following hypothesis:
Hypothesis 3: The severity of psychological distress has a significant positive impact on precautionary saving

Physical exercise can induce structural and functional changes in the brain, which enormously benefit cognitive functioning and well-being (Fernandes et al. 2017). In addition, it prevents neurodegeneration (Mandolesi et al. 2018). Due to the contagious virus risk during the lockdown, conventional sports activities are limited because of restriction rules (Ruth et al. 2022). To maintain health activities and prevention, people have begun to conduct digital home training as an alternative solution that has become widely accepted (Fadahunsi et al. 2021). How will online exercise training influences precautionary saving when a contagious risk exists? First, to our knowledge, there is no such direct empirical evidence. However, cognitive performance is demonstrated to be influenced by physical exercise (Lista and Sorrentino 2010; Fernandes et al. 2017) that facilitates neurotrophic factors released and sequentially beneficial to blood flow and cerebrovascular health (Hötting et al. 2016). A higher level of cognitive processing results in improved memory, attentional, and executive-control processes (Chieffi et al. 2017). In addition, cognitive ability is positively associated with prudence (Noussair et al. 2014; Breaban et al. 2016), and prudent people tend to save in advance to guard against unforeseen expenditures and plan for the future (Ventura and Eisenhauer 2006). Therefore, we propose the following hypothesis:
Hypothesis 4: digital media-based physical exercises have a significant positive effect on the precautionary saving

sec.title: Survey and inclusion criteria
sec.p: Cross-sectional research was carried out in Shanghai just after the lockdown was released. We launched an online questionnaire survey on a professional platform called WJX (https://www.wjx.cn/), which offers survey distribution and data collection services and has been widely acknowledged by well-ranked journals.

WJX randomly distributed surveys in Shanghai. The informed content form was offered to participants, and they approved by signing it. After that, participants clicked the link to answer the questionnaire. The Ethics Committee of the Shanwei Institute of Technology approved the research proposal.

A total of 1325 questionnaires were collected in this survey, with 1016 valid questionnaires and 309 invalid questionnaires (cases with missing values, fast processors, apparently fictitious values, and inconsistency with the questions), and the questionnaire validity rate was 76.68%. Only those aged 18–60 years employed and living in Shanghai during the lockdown were kept for further analysis. To justify the sample size, we know the number of employed people in Shanghai in 2020 was around 13.74 million (Data source: China: number of employees in Shanghai 2000–2020 from Statista), and we set the margin of error as 5% and the confidence level as 95%, which indicates a sample size of at least 385 people would be necessary. Therefore, we have enough samples.

sec.title: Data collection and measurement
sec.p: Data on socio-demographic characteristics, consisting of gender, age, marital status, children less than 12 years old, education attainment, annual household income, income risk; mental health, implementing digital media-based sports activities; individuals’ willingness to get a COVID-19 vaccine, and precaution saving were collected through the questionnaire.

Digital sports activities. We measure it with a question in Chinese proposed by Mutz et al. (2021): Please think of the last six months: Have you used videos, online programs, or other digital media for sports activities at home? We code 1 if replied with “yes”; otherwise 0.

Mental health. We assess it with a series of six questions that are utilized to construct the K-6 scores (Kessler et al. 2003), which are good at predicting depression and anxiety (Bogan and Fertig 2018). Respondents are asked to grade feelings on a scale of 0 (none of the time) to 4 (all of the time) as follows: (1) whether has felt sad, (2) nervous, (3) restless, (4) hopeless, (5) worthless, and (6) everything was an effort during the Shanghai lockdown. After summing these scores, a summary score is created, arranged from 0 to 24. Higher scores indicate one is severely psychologically distressed.

Willingness to get vaccinated. We elicit it by asking, “Do you plan to get all doses of a coronavirus vaccine when available” which is proposed by Qin et al. (2021). We assign 1 to it if the respondent replies “yes”; otherwise, 0.

Precautionary saving. We compute an indicator of it, which equals one if the respondent replies “yes” to “After experiencing the lockdown in Shanghai, have you or your household increased the amount you save for coping with unforeseen events, such as unemployment, health, or other emergencies?” (Immordino et al. 2022); otherwise 0.

Socio-demographic characteristics as control variables. They include factors of individuals or households that can influence current willingness to get vaccinated and precautionary savings to mitigate endogenous problems and avoid biased estimates: Age consists of 5 ranges coded in sequence: 24 and less (1), 25–34 (2), 35–44 (3), 45–54 (4), 55 and more (5); Annual household income consists of 5 ranges coded sequentially as well: less than 20,000 (1), 20,000–50,000 (2), 50,001–100,000 (3), 100,001–20,000 (4), 20,001 and more (5).

Male is dichotomous, equal to 1 if the respondent is a male; otherwise, 0. Marital status equals one if the respondent is married; otherwise, 0; Higher education is binary, which equals one if the respondent has higher education attainment; otherwise 0. Children under 12 equal one if the respondent has a child less than 12 years old; otherwise, 0.

More importantly, we include an income risk dummy variable because it determines the probability of increased savings and decreased consumption (Immordino et al. 2022). It equals one if the respondent selects (1), (2), or (3) from “During the Shanghai lockdown, which sentences best describe your work situation? (1) I have lost my job; (2) I still have a job but expect to lose it in the next six months; (3) I still have a job but am working fewer hours than before the crisis; (4) My job position has remained stable; (5) I have found a (first or new) job; (6) I do not work and am not working before the crisis.”; otherwise 0.

sec.title: Econometrics model
sec.p: We use a logistic regression model to test the effect of psychological distress (hypothesis 1) and engaging in digital sports activities (hypothesis 2) on willingness to take three doses of the COVID vaccine because the latter variable is dichotomously measured. Logistic regression has several advantages. First, no normal distribution assumption is required for either the dependent or the independent variables. Second, the corresponding error terms are not assumed to be normally distributed. Third, the relationships between the independent and dependent variables are not considered linear.
To test the above hypotheses, we used Stata 17.1.

Demographically, 45.4% of survey participants were male. The majority of them were between 25 and 54 years old, 76.7% of respondents were married, 92.3% of them received higher education, 47.6% of them had children who were less than 12 years old, and 28.8% of respondents faced income risk.

A total of 904 respondents (89%) would like to take all vaccine doses, and they (708 [69.69%]) increased bank savings to deal with the risk of unemployment, health crisis, or any other emergency after this lockdown. A substantial percentage of respondents reduced their durable (757 [74.5%]) and non-durable (698 [68.7%]) consumption during isolation.

In addition, results indicate that doing online sports positively correlates with willingness to take all vaccine doses, which supports hypothesis 2. In particular, compared with those who did not use digital media for sports activity during the lockdown, the probability of taking all vaccine doses for those who did is 8.1% higher.

Furthermore, results point out that marital status is positively associated with the willingness to take all vaccine doses. Particularly, compared with those who did not marry, the probability of taking all vaccine doses for those who did is 10.3% higher.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the present study, we investigated whether psychological distress and digital sports activities influence individuals’ willingness to take vaccines and to save under the zero-COVID policy. This research provides some important insights by analyzing representative survey data collected during and after the COVID-19 pandemic in Shanghai.

sec.title: Mental health and the willingness for COVID-19 vaccination
sec.p: Our results demonstrated that mental health problems harm willingness to take COVID-19 vaccine doses. Scholars call for papers to assess the effect of mental health problems on COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy (i.e., will not take vaccine doses) (Smith et al. 2020; Warren et al. 2021; Payberah et al. 2022). This research is the first empirical evidence relating mental health to COVID-19 vaccination in China. Historically, the uptake of similar vaccines in individuals with mental health problems was reported. For example, the percentage of influenza vaccination in people with severe mental illness was approximately 25% (Lorenz et al. 2013), which indicates a negative relationship between mental health and vaccination. More recently, there are psychological determinants of COVID-19 vaccine hesitancy (Gerretsen et al. 2021), including mistrust of the vaccine, lower perceived seriousness of COVID-19, right-wing political affiliation, higher risk propensity, and emotional effects. However, that finding is based on the US and Canada sample and focused more on the impact of general psychological determinants, rather than mental health, on vaccine hesitancy.

Reasons to hesitate to take COVID-19 vaccines for individuals with mental health problems vary (Warren et al. 2021). First, individual barriers include vaccine awareness and education. People who are psychologically distressed take negative beliefs about safety and misconceptions that the vaccine itself can bring about the illness (Lorenz et al. 2013). They fear infection and experience contemporary general anxiety. Solutions to individual barriers could include developing vaccine education and awareness programs in terms of mental health professionals discussing vaccinations for preventive health, discussing physical health comorbidity and risks of COVID-19, and advocating for vaccination programs, which are expected to address safety concerns and vaccine misconceptions. Second, systemic barriers to vaccination involve access, acceptability, awareness of services, cost, and other practical considerations. The corresponding solutions could be establishing vaccination clinics near mental health services (Miles et al. 2020), concurrent family vaccination (Osam et al. 2020), and taking vaccines for free (Lorenz et al. 2013).

sec.title: Digital sports and the willingness for COVID-19 vaccination
sec.p: In addition, results showed that digital sports practitioners are more willing to take the COVID-19 vaccination. Previously published studies regarding the relationship between physical activity and vaccine hesitancy are mixed. On one hand, our results are in line with some literature. For example, elderly Europeans who participate in healthy behavior are more likely to require flu vaccination (Schmitz and Wübker 2011). Sufficient physical activity predicts influenza vaccine uptake in Singaporean older adults (Ang et al. 2017). More recently and directly, physical activity is significantly associated with COVID-19 vaccination uptake in Pakistani (Zakar et al. 2022), and regular physical activity engagers in Asia are more inclined to COVID-19 vaccination (Chew et al. 2021).

Therefore, detecting the underlying channels, from digital sports to vaccination willingness, is essential. Digital sports activities are all sports and exercise activities that are essentially supported by digital media and digital equipment, such as live-streamed exercises or Smartphone apps (Mutz et al. 2021). During the pandemic, lockdown restrictions led to a drastic decline in physical activity worldwide (Wilke et al. 2021). Given that sufficient physical activity predicts vaccination willingness (Ang et al. 2017) and digital sports increase the motivation to move and stay active (Gowin et al. 2015; Mokmin and Jamiat 2021), health awareness and literacy could be one channel for digital sports practitioners to protect their health and use vaccination against COVID-19 or its variants in pandemic times. Another channel could be the perception of their susceptibility to COVID-19-associated health problems and their preventive attitudes during that period (Nania et al. 2021; Zakar et al. 2022).

On the other hand, the present study’s findings are inconsistent with other studies. For example, parents refuse to let their children be vaccinated but promote physical activity and other preventative behaviors. Similarly, instead of immunization, parents in Quebec had confidence in protecting their children’s physical activity, good air, and other preventive actions (Guay et al. 2019). We argue that these studies were implemented before the coronavirus disease pandemic, and this disease is very harmful to the health and development of children (Tso et al. 2020). Encouraging children to engage in physical activity is not an alternative solution but a motivator to take the vaccine because sports do not guarantee they are immune to COVID-19.

It is worth mentioning that people who are married have a propensity for getting vaccinated, which is consistent with previous findings (Okubo et al. 2021; Wu et al. 2021b), and its average marginal effect is even more than the one of psychological distress or digital sports. Several reasons may explain this finding. First, unmarried people often are active social media users and the anti-vaccine movement reported on social media may increase their prejudices against vaccination (Murphy et al. 2021). Second, single people living alone tend to wait for effective vaccines and further assessment. On the contrary, people in a marriage are more likely to get vaccinated because they intend to prevent themselves and their families from getting the disease (Konopińska et al. 2021).

sec.title: Mental health and increased savings
sec.p: Our study found that psychological distress is positively associated with the probability of an increase in savings, which was in line with previous research findings. A US study reported that people with psychological disorders cut investments in risky assets, and single women having mental health issues add to savings (Bogan and Fertig 2013). More recently, European aging households influenced by mental health issues reduce the probability of having risky elements (Lindeboom and Melnychuk 2015).

Knowing the possible channels behind the association is essential because it will result in a better understanding of financial behavior and propose appropriate policies to make saving decisions better. We argue that mental health issues could change individual perceptions (Wu et al. 2021a), reduces the willingness to take a risk (Li et al. 2021), and, consequently, invest in safe assets. Alternatively, mental health problems reduce problem-solving ability via cognitive abilities (Yen et al. 2011), which are associated with organizing and processing information. Therefore, individuals with mental illnesses face difficulties processing financial information (Schubert et al. 2022). The third possible channel could be the planning horizon, which refers to the time horizon by which people decide how to save and consume. Psychologically distressed individuals are inclined to be shortsighted and plan their finances over a shorter horizon. It is documented that depression is associated with a shorter financial planning horizon and eventually leads to present-oriented savings and consumption (Choung et al. 2022).

sec.title: Digital sports and precautionary savings
sec.p: Our results indicated a positive association between home-based sports activities with digital media and precautionary savings, demonstrating that physical activities can influence precautionary savings.

Before discussing possible explanations of the association between physical activity and precautionary saving, it is worth noting in the first review that uncertainty in future income significantly affects saving decisions theoretically. Known examples include but are not limited to disorders in financial, economic, and political fields, which could cause future income uncertainty raised and further result in an increase in savings (Lugilde et al. 2019). In addition, socio-demographic information (such as gender, age, marital status, children, and education) also explains individual heterogeneity in saving behaviors (Lugilde et al. 2019). More recently, it has been reported that the likelihood of increasing savings after the pandemic is positively affected by fear of COVID-19 contagion (Immordino et al. 2022). The present study adds to the developing literature on precautionary saving for the period of the COVID-19 pandemic. It is novel in that it gives information on physical activities based on digital media.

Plausible channels are health reliefs and cognitive functioning. First, we hypothesize that people who routinely use digital media to engage in sports activities during the lockdown would be more likely to have substantial health beliefs (Haase et al. 2004), resulting in saving money to get necessary supplies in the uncertain future, such as nutrient-rich food, masks, and fitness equipment. Alternatively, as physical activities are associated with cognitive functioning (Martin et al. 2018; Erickson et al. 2019; Powell et al. 2018), cognitive abilities are positively related to precautionary behavior (Thoma et al. 2021); consequently, physical activities predict precautionary saving. In other words, physically active individuals are more likely to know the mechanisms of transmission and infectiousness of COVID-19. They increase their saving buffer to hedge against infection and income risk.

sec.title: Practical implications
sec.p: The present paper has some practical implications. To increase the willingness to accept vaccination, policymakers should reduce the public’s psychological distress and advocate video-based physical activities during the COVID-19 pandemic, which help address concerns about the vaccine’s side effects and mitigate hesitancy to vaccination. Particular solutions could be offering services to citizens, especially for those with psychological distress, for example, mental care, psychological counseling, vaccine education to raise health literacy, free video-based lessons for physical activities (Mutz et al. 2021), government vouchers for digital devices (e.g., mobile phone, pads, laptops), sports clubs and gyms incorporate digital activities into their products portfolio, monitoring uptake among people who are still not vaccinated, vaccination recommendation within mental health services and helpline, and tailoring messages to boost confidence in vaccines (Warren et al. 2021; Nguyen et al. 2022).

sec.title: Theoretical contributions
sec.p: Researchers claim that many substantial decisions are regularly made under uncertainty (Guo et al. 2022). The uncertainty caused by COVID-19 is massive, including virus infectiousness, the time to accomplish vaccines, the possibility of new outbreaks, the duration of social distancing policy, the economic impact, the speed of economic recovery after the pandemic, changed saving and consumption behaviors (Altig et al. 2020). The findings in the present study have a theoretical implication by demonstrating mental health status and digital media-based physical activities predict the likelihood of an increase in saving that is a reaction to economic uncertainty caused by COVID-19. Precautional saving is lately under considerable attention (Brown and Cowling 2021). Our results help to understand that different sources of uncertainty play different roles in total saving and consumption, which would be essential to choose the right policies to increase investment and recover economics after the pandemic (Vergara and Bonilla 2021).

sec.title: Research limitations and future research directions
sec.p: This research has several limitations. First, the randomly selected sample might not be an accurately representative Shanghai population because respondents to online surveys tend to be well-educated. Less educated people may be less covered. Second, region particularities may exist because this study was conducted within Shanghai. Future studies could take notice of these limitations and do in-depth research.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Using new data from a recent survey of 1016 Shanghai residents, we investigate the impact of psychological distress and digital media-based sports activities during the lockdown on the willingness for COVID-19 vaccination and precautionary saving.

Our results could be a vital reference for the government, mental health providers, fitness clubs, and gyms. On the one hand, psychologically distressed individuals are less inclined to take the vaccine, which calls for easy access to mental health hotlines and psychological counseling for those quarantined people. On the other hand, those persons who engage in fitness activities via social media platforms are more willing to get vaccinated. Therefore, offering purchase vouchers for digital products and free-charged online practice lessons would effectively advocate physical activities for increasing vaccine uptake. Other solutions could be outreach and vaccine education, vaccine effectiveness broadcast, and monitoring uptake among individuals who have not been vaccinated.

Moreover, we also find individuals who were psychologically distressed and digital video-based physically active had a stronger precautionary saving motivation, which made theoretical contributions to literature in economics and psychology by detecting new factors that influence precautionary saving behavior during the pandemic.
